name: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT)
summary: A mindfulness-based behavioral therapy that emphasizes acceptance, psychological flexibility, and values-driven action to reduce suffering and improve well-being.
description: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) is a form of psychotherapy rooted in behavioral and mindfulness traditions. It helps individuals develop psychological flexibility by teaching them to accept unpleasant thoughts and feelings, defuse from unhelpful cognitions, clarify personal values, and commit to behavior aligned with those values. Rather than eliminating symptoms, ACT focuses on fostering resilience, reducing avoidance, and building a meaningful life.

clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong; supported by numerous RCTs across multiple conditions.
clinical_metadata.research_support: ACT has a robust evidence base for anxiety, depression, chronic pain, and stress-related disorders.

sections.text: ACT works by cultivating psychological flexibility. Through mindfulness, acceptance strategies, and cognitive defusion, individuals learn to reduce the impact of unhelpful thoughts and emotions. By clarifying core values and committing to aligned action, ACT helps patients pursue meaningful lives despite ongoing difficulties.

sections.preparation: Initial assessment of symptoms, values, and coping strategies.
procedure: Teach defusion techniques to separate self from thoughts.
Develop behavior change goals aligned with values.

sections.pre_session: Review previous practice, check current symptoms.
sections.treatment_phase: Engage in mindfulness, defusion, acceptance, and values work.
sections.post_session: Commit to new behavior aligned with values.
sections.home_practice: Daily mindfulness practice and values-based actions.

immediate: Increased awareness of thoughts and feelings

common: Temporary discomfort when facing avoided emotions
rare: Exacerbation of distress in unstable psychiatric conditions

special_considerations: Adapt interventions for trauma survivors carefully

ideal_candidates: Individuals with anxiety, depression, or chronic pain
Patients motivated to pursue values-based goals
Those who struggle with experiential avoidance
screening_required: Assessment of psychiatric stability and readiness for mindfulness

practitioner: Licensed mental health professionals with ACT training

studies: Meta-analyses support ACT for anxiety, depression, and chronic pain.
Evidence suggests ACT is as effective as CBT for many conditions, with unique emphasis on values and acceptance.
sections.limitations: Not all patients engage with mindfulness; requires consistent practice.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Varies widely based on duration, typically $1,000–$3,000
sections.cost_effectiveness: Considered cost-effective due to broad applicability across conditions

sections.adolescents: Adapted protocols exist and are effective for teens with anxiety and depression
sections.elderly: Useful for coping with chronic illness and loss
sections.pregnancy: Safe and beneficial for stress management
sections.comorbidities: Applicable across psychiatric and medical comorbidities

items: ACT emphasizes living a valued life rather than eliminating symptoms.
Psychological flexibility is the core therapeutic process.
Can be delivered in group, individual, or digital formats.

items.label: Hayes SC, et al. Acceptance and Commitment Therapy: Model, processes and outcomes. Behaviour Research and Therapy. 2006.
A-Tjak JGL, et al. A meta-analysis of the efficacy of acceptance and commitment therapy for clinically relevant mental and physical health problems. Psychotherapy and Psychosomatics. 2015.

seo.title: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) | Mindfulness-Based CBT
seo.description: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) is an evidence-based, mindfulness-based behavioral therapy that builds psychological flexibility, values-based action, and resilience against anxiety, depression, and chronic pain.
